This bug was also reported on the mailing list by two other people:

http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.platform/msg12130.html
http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.platform/msg12208.html

Here is another message in the mailing list about this problem:
  http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.platform/msg11621.html

From this posting:
  The problem I guess was that I did not had default empty
  constructor. When extending my plugin from AbstractUIPlugin
  I had to provide one. But this create incompatability with
  AbstractUIPlugin (it has only one implicit constructor
  AbstractUIPlugin(IPluginDescriptor descriptor)). It is not
  possible just set it to "null" in super() call because
  you'll fail on assertion. I guess it is possible to mock it,
  but I didn't go further. Instead I just extended my plugin
  from Plugin class.

If I derrive my Plugin from org.eclipse.core.runtime.Plugin instead of 
org.eclipse.ui.plugin.AbstractUIPlugin, and add an empty constructor!!, I have 
no problem.

I tryed to remove the dependency on org.eclipse.osgi from the plugin.xml, but 
(for some reasons, I don't understand), I cannot. If I do so, I the the 
following error: 
  The project was not built since its build path is incomplete. 
  Cannot find the class file for org.osgi.framework.BundleActivator. 
  Fix the build path then try rebuilding this project.

I have no idea what generates this dependeny....

As a point of interest, are you writing your own manifest.mf or are you putting 
the runtime related mark up in the plugin.xml?  The question I really want to 
ask is "what is you bundle activator class"

OK, all I do is to try to port some 2.1.2 plugins to 3.0. Therefore I use the
plugin.xml. I have no knowledge of OSGI (except I know in principle what it is)
and I am not using it currently (so, no manifest.mf). I was surprized that
eclipse forces me to depend on the osgi plugin. I thought that osgi would be
invisible to me....

Can you outline the steps you took to "port" your plugin?  That is, what tools 
if any did you use, etc.

I ask because all of Eclipse and other products run with no changes and no 
knowledge of OSGi.  I suspect that something has been upset during your porting 
process.  either that or you have a usecase that is new to us and is not 
correctly handled.

You certainly should not not have to know about OSGi unless you want to.

The same happens to me when I deploy our plugins targetted originally at Eclipse
2.1.2 into the 3.0M6 version. The upper part of the stacktrace is exactly the
same, although in our case, the exception gets thrown during adding a nature to
project's description.

I have done no porting as far as I can tell.

I have two dependent plugins: ...schema.core and ...schema.ui (ui depends on
core). The UI plugin activates fine, and can show a Wizard. When the Wizard
attempts to add nature ID to the project description (nature is registered by
the core plugin), this exception is thrown.
The ui plugin declares proper dependency on core (and works fine on Eclipse 2.1.2)

I just got the same error when I tried to execute an action from the releng
plug-in using I20040203. Adding
      <import plugin="org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility" optional="true"/>
to the required plug-ins section fixed the problem.

Here is what it seems to be happening: plug-ins not having a <?eclipse
version="3.0"?> tag or requiring org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility are
considered old-style plugins, that need more complete support for backwards
compatibility. The plugin class for new plugins must have a no-arg constructor
(as BundleActivators do). The plugin class for old plugins must have a
constructor taking a IPluginDescriptor.

It also happens that currently PDE generates plugin manifests that are tagged as
3.0 but have an old style plug-in class (which inherits from AbstractUIPlugin) -
I just opened a PR to handle this issue: bug 51206.

For completeness: the instantiation exception happens because (as pointed out in
comnment 3) the plugin class constructor does not match its plugin style.

>the plugin class constructor does not match its plugin style.
Can you comment a bit more on that. The plug-in has:

	/**
	 * The constructor.
	 */
	public RelEngPlugin(IPluginDescriptor descriptor) {

What's wrong with that? Most Eclipse plug-ins have this and only this constructor.

Note: The plug-in has <?eclipse version="3.0"?> tag 

Also note: there must be some changes in recent builds (meaning in the last 1 or
2 weeks) which changed in that area since we could use the releng plug-in before
without problems.

A 3.0 plug-in that is not in backward compatibility mode (from the viewpoint of
runtime/OSGi) has a plugin class whose constructor takes no arguments (yours is
an example of one that requires 2.1 style support from runtime). 

Currently, a plugin is consided "new style" if it has the <?eclipse
version="3.0"?> processing instruction *and* does not require
org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility.

Your problem is that your original manifest was for a "new style" plugin,
although your plugin class has a 2.1 style constructor (expecting
IPluginDescriptor). Requiring org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility tells
runtime that your plug-in is a 2.1 style plug-in (again, from the runtime point
of view - the "eclipse" processing instruction has a broader meaning).

Pascal, Jeff, comments?

Thanks for the info. I filed bug 51239 against Platform Releng which own the
tool. It surprised my because it did not strike me when OSGi came into life but
with a recent build.

Keeping the PR open so Jeff/Pascal can confirm the observed behavior is what is
expected (I don't think this is documented anywhere yet).

the Plugin class has to have the default constructor IF it is used as the 
Bundle-Activator.  The default transformation of the plugin.xml to manifest.mf 
puts a standard backward compatibility bundle activator in the manifest.mf as 
the activator and lists the Plugin class in another header.  when the 
compatibility activator is run, it looks at this other header and 
creates/invokes the plugin class as normal.

Pascal put in some code recently which was supposed to make this more backward 
compatible but we may have gotten it wrong.  I;ll try to find pascal and ask 
about it.  

Marking as M7 P1
Hmmm... so it seems bug 51206 is invalid...

Please advise as to whether it makes sense to provide a 0-arg constructor in 
AbstractUIPlugin.

AbstractUIPlugin must provide a 0-arg constructor to allow real bundles to 
inherits from AbstractUIPlugin.
I think this fixis already in.

Just for clarity, let's summarize the different behavior that are / should be 
supported.

1 - Unconverted 2.1 plugin. The bundle activator will be the default activator 
provided by runtime (PluginActivator) and the plugin-class specified in the 
plugin.xml will be used.

2 - Plugin.xml containing eclipse 3.0 tag, and requirements containing 
org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility. The bundle activator will be the 
default activator provided by runtime (PluginActivator) and the plugin-class 
specified in the plugin.xml will be used.

2 - Plugin.xml containing eclipse 3.0 tag, the requires DO NOT contain a 
reference to org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility. The plugin-class specified 
in the plugin.xml will be used as a BundleActivator which requires the plugin-
class to have a 0-arg constructor, as well as all the classes in its hierarchy.

This last use case depicts a situation where people really want to take 
advantage of the new OSGi runtime.
Decreasing priority since the issue is understood.

Michael, could you try if you can still reproduce the problem with one of 
today's I-Build?
I still have the same problem :-(

Could you provide the plugin.xml and your plugin class (or at least all the 
signatures)

Created an attachment (id=8001)
Simple plugin that demonstrates the problem

Hi...I just hit this.	I'm on M7.

At first I thought that M7 just didn't have the AbstractUIPlugin with the
no-arg constructor, but I checked and it's there.   So I tried adding a no-arg
constructor into my plugin and it worked!:

public xxx () {super();}

I whipped up a simple testcase for this by taking the Hello World PDE sample
and taking the runtime compatibility off of the class path and putting the 3.0
runtime on.  If you try to use the Sample Menu you get "Operation not
available...", but if you add the no-arg constructor it will work.   

I suppose it could be a ClassLoader problem, but I've tried on IBM JRE 1.4.1
and and early version of IBM JRE 1.4.2, so I would suspect it's somewhere in
the OSGI layer.

Thanks...
*** Bug 52799 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Note, there likely was a problem in M6 but it has long since been fixed.

As for the current behaviour, we don't believe it to be a problem 
(compatibility or otherwise). Comment 19 describes exactly what is going on.  

The first thing to note is that 2.1 plugins continue to work unchanged.

Next, plugins marked as <?eclipse version=3.0?> and requiring 
runtime.compatibility also continue to work unchanged.

It is only if you are wanting to get off the compatibility layer (why?) that 
you actually need to change your plugin class to have the zero arg constructor.

Note that if your plugin class is exposed as API for others to subclass then 
they cannot get off compatibility until you do as there has to be a zero arg 
constructor all the way up the hierarchy.

Closing.

I didn't do anything as malicious as removing the compatibility from the 
classpath when I first hit this (that was only to reproduce the problem).  I 
believe that all I did was open my 2.1 plugin in the PDE, and hit PDE Tools -> 
Migrate to 3.0 and then my plugin wouldn't load when I tried to run it.  

If the Migrate to 3.0 Tool does add the compatibility to the classpath, then I 
suppose it's possible I had some other errors in my workspace that prevented 
my manifest from being properly updated.

I can't judge in how far this is relevant, but I can give a counter-example of 
the statement "The first thing to note is that 2.1 plugins continue to work 
unchanged." in comment #26. 
 
I'm using together-for-eclipse 6.2 (also tried 6.1) and I used to get similar 
errors as in other comments in this bug report. Today, I tried Feb. 26's 
integration build, and I can't even seem to install it anymore. (Before, some 
together views did work)..  
 
Anyway, if 2.1 plugin compatability is a real goal for eclipse 3, it seems to 
me it hasn't been achieved yet. However, if it isn't a goal (and I understand 
it may be impossible to achieve 100% compatability), maybe there should be a 
kind of warning at startup.
